Thank you for your answer. 
Am I right? JUnit generates his own reports for=
 failed tests? How can 
I catch them? Or what do you mean with reports for =
aggregate 
information? Are that reports different from the logging I gener=
ate 
with eg log4j?

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@... wrote:
>
> Th=
at sounds like two different things:
> 
> The logging, whether through log4=
j (which I also like) or something 
else, will provide debugging informatio=
n to you.
> 
> The reports are useful for aggregate information (like how m=
any 
failures and errors for X number of tests for the whole product 
suite=
, or whatever scope you run) and information about tests passed 
and failed=
 (errors and failures).
> 
> For the tests that failed, you might use the i=
nformation from the 
report (which will give you information around the iss=
ue - stack 
trace or failure information) or information from the log files=
 
(information for the entire run - you might be able to see the 
progressi=
on of state that led to the failure/error) to troubleshoot 
and fix.
> 
> I=
 generally take the reports, or the result of an individual run, 
as my sta=
rting point, and then only look at the logging for the ones 
that failed in=
 some way.  If I have written my asserts well, I 
usually don't even need t=
o look at the logging, because I will know 
exactly what went wrong.
> 
> H=
ope this helps and good luck on the migration.
> 
> 
> Dianne
> 
> --------=
